citations.narrative:
There were no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand for the goats, sheep, pigs, deer, or birds available at
the time of inspection. Complete and accurate animal records must be kept current and made available during inspection
to facilitate the identification and tracking of animals as well as ensure their health and well-being. Records must be
maintained, which fully and correctly disclose all the required information concerning all animals purchased or otherwise
acquired, owned, held, leased, transported, sold, euthanized or otherwise disposed of and shall include any offspring born
or hatched while in the licensee’s possession.
Correct by 05/05/2025.

In the upper courtyard pen, there was a plastic bottom trough of one of the hay feed bunks which was broken and split
into several sections with some pointed ends. Also, there was an approximately 3ft. section of welded wire panel which
has come loose from the bottom of a wooden support beam leaving a 1 ft. open gap with several exposed nail heads.
In the goat hill pen, there were several sections of fencing with loose or broken and protruding wires. There were two
large wooden posts connected by several feet of loose wire lying on the ground and up against the fencing. Also, an
approximately 1ft. section of wire fencing along the sides of the bridge plank leading to this pen has detached leaving an
open gap.
The animals could possibly become caught or trapped in any loose wiring or open gaps in fencing. Additionally, they may
become injured from sharp, protruding wire or plastic ends or from ingesting pieces of loose plastic from the feed bunk. All
housing facilities and animal areas must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury and to contain the animals. A system of timely identification, facility repair and maintenance must be in place.
Correct by 05/05/2025.

There is a general accumulation of cobwebs, dust and debris collecting along the ceilings, upper walls and in the corners
of several animal rooms and enclosures. The majority of the ceiling of the deer enclosure was covered with thick cobwebs
which were approximately 1ft.X 1 ft. in size. Accumulations of cobwebs, dust and debris in any area where animals are
housed may negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals including possible respiratory problems, attracting
pests, and other disease hazards.
The premises must be kept clean and in good repair in order to facilitate the required husbandry practices and to protect
the health and well-being of the animals. A system of timely and effective cleaning and housekeeping must be in place.
Correct by 05/05/2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
There were no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand for the goats, sheep, pigs, deer, or birds available at 
the time of inspection. Complete and accurate animal records must be kept current and made available during inspection 
to facilitate the identification and tracking of animals as well as ensure their health and well-being. Records must be 
maintained, which fully and correctly disclose all the required information concerning all animals purchased or otherwise 
acquired, owned, held, leased, transported, sold, euthanized or otherwise disposed of and shall include any offspring born 
or hatched while in the licensee’s possession. 
 
Correct by 05/05/2025. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In the upper courtyard pen, there was a plastic bottom trough of one of the hay feed bunks which was broken and split 
into several sections with some pointed ends. Also, there was an approximately 3ft. section of welded wire panel which 
has come loose from the bottom of a wooden support beam leaving a 1 ft. open gap with several exposed nail heads. 
 
In the goat hill pen, there were several sections of fencing with loose or broken and protruding wires. There were two 
large wooden posts connected by several feet of loose wire lying on the ground and up against the fencing. Also, an 
approximately 1ft. section of wire fencing along the sides of the bridge plank leading to this pen has detached leaving an 
open gap.  
 
The animals could possibly become caught or trapped in any loose wiring or open gaps in fencing. Additionally, they may 
become injured from sharp, protruding wire or plastic ends or from ingesting pieces of loose plastic from the feed bunk. All 
housing facilities and animal areas must be structurally sound and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury and to contain the animals. A system of timely identification, facility repair and maintenance must be in place. 
 
Correct by 05/05/2025. 
3.131(c)

Sanitation. 
There is a general accumulation of cobwebs, dust and debris collecting along the ceilings, upper walls and in the corners 
of several animal rooms and enclosures. The majority of the ceiling of the deer enclosure was covered with thick cobwebs 
which were approximately 1ft.X 1 ft. in size. Accumulations of cobwebs, dust and debris in any area where animals are 
housed may negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals including possible respiratory problems, attracting 
pests, and other disease hazards. 
The premises must be kept clean and in good repair in order to facilitate the required husbandry practices and to protect 
the health and well-being of the animals. A system of timely and effective cleaning and housekeeping must be in place. 
 
Correct by 05/05/2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
